By TOM STONE, Sports Editor

This is the second in a series of articles on the Hopkins athletic
program by Torn Stone, sports editor of the News-Letter. ,
The Purpose Of Athletics

Athletics at M.I.T. are a part of our educational program.
They are managed in a way to be of maximum value to the
individual student. As a result, we are happily free from
the pressures and over-emphasis which have stigmatized
college athletics out of the hands of students.
We engage in extensive intercollegiate competition.
We like to win. We believe athletics to be an essential and
delightful part of the student life. Our policy is to provide
opportunities to play hard, to play to win, to have fun, but to
achieve these ends in a true spirit and in a manner that makes
athletics a wholesome supplement to education and an appropriate part of well-rounded student life.
DI. JAMES R. KILLIAN, JR.
President, Massachusetts
Institute of Technology.
Those are words which very concisely summarize nearly the
total athletic picture at an institution where athletic activities
are run on a level very near that of The Hopkins. In those
short paragraphs Dr. Killian brings out one of the best stated
purposes for any college to have. That is the pnrpose of making
"athletics a wholesome supplement to education and an appropriate part of well-rounded student life." Ivan J. Geiger, Director
of Athletics at the Institute, sets the aim of providing "meaningful
athletic activities" as his goal in setting,up the athletic program
there. "The primary objectives," according to Mr. Geiger, "are
the promotion of physical and mental fitness, social efficiency,
and culture through sane participation."
"Compete On An Honorable Basis"

Swarthmore College's athletic head, Willis J. Stetson, says
the following in discussing that College's program:"Swarthmore
College, like any normal institution, wishes to see its teams win
their share of contests. But it does not place such undue emphasis
on winning that 'to win at any cost' becomes the guiding slogan:
Our emphasis is on participation and we feel that with diversified
schedules, proficient instruction, and proper spirit, we can compete
on an honorable basis with our opponents."
That's the story on two places of higher learning similar to
ours who also have comparable athletic policies. Last week
The 'Nester stated the aims of our program as set-forth by the
administrators of such. These aims were (1) to put athletics in
the proper place of the university program and, (2) to place
proper emphasis on such in an educational institution such as
ours. They are generalized statements, but the Hopkins principals are sure to go along with the goals of M.I.T. and Swarthmore.
Since all the colleges and universities (Hopkins, Swarthmore,
V. of Chicago, Haverfoid, M.I.T., Amherst, Oberlin and Harvard)
represented in the series of articles published in The North Central
Association Quarterly last spring agree in purpose you'd no
doubt think they must have similar over-all programs. However,
this is not the case as will be brought out in future weeks.

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor

This is the second in a series of articles on the Hopkins athletic

The Purpose Of Athletics

Athletics at M.I.T. are a part of our educational program.
They are managed in a way to be of maximum value to the
individual student. As a result, we are happily free from
the pressures and over-emphasis which have stigmatized
college athletics out of the hands of students.
We engage in extensive intercollegiate competition.
We like to win. We believe athletics to be an essential and
delightful part of the student life. Our policy is to provide
opportunities to play hard, to play to win, to have fun, but to
achieve these ends in a true spirit and in a manner that makes
athletics a wholesome supplement to education and an appropriate part of well-rounded student life.
DI. JAMES R. KILLIAN, JR.
President, Massachusetts
Institute of Technology.
Those are words which very concisely summarize nearly the
total athletic picture at an institution where athletic activities
are run on a level very near that of The Hopkins. In those
short paragraphs Dr. Killian brings out one of the best stated
purposes for any college to have. That is the pnrpose of making
"athletics a wholesome supplement to education and an appropriate part of well-rounded student life." Ivan J. Geiger, Director
of Athletics at the Institute, sets the aim of providing "meaningful
athletic activities" as his goal in setting,up the athletic program
there. "The primary objectives," according to Mr. Geiger, "are
the promotion of physical and mental fitness, social efficiency,
and culture through sane participation."
"Compete On An Honorable Basis"

Swarthmore College's athletic head, Willis J. Stetson, says
the following in discussing that College's program:"Swarthmore
College, like any normal institution, wishes to see its teams win
their share of contests. But it does not place such undue emphasis
on winning that 'to win at any cost' becomes the guiding slogan:
Our emphasis is on participation and we feel that with diversified
schedules, proficient instruction, and proper spirit, we can compete
on an honorable basis with our opponents."
That's the story on two places of higher learning similar to
ours who also have comparable athletic policies. Last week
The 'Nester stated the aims of our program as set-forth by the
administrators of such. These aims were (1) to put athletics in
the proper place of the university program and, (2) to place
proper emphasis on such in an educational institution such as
ours. They are generalized statements, but the Hopkins principals are sure to go along with the goals of M.I.T. and Swarthmore.
Since all the colleges and universities (Hopkins, Swarthmore,
V. of Chicago, Haverfoid, M.I.T., Amherst, Oberlin and Harvard)
represented in the series of articles published in The North Central
Association Quarterly last spring agree in purpose you'd no
doubt think they must have similar over-all programs. However,
this is not the case as will be brought out in future weeks.
